4fd678b0-adee-496e-bd67-62b03cc17f8e.description: The course objective is to educate all computer users. The general course topics include cyber ethics overview and terminology; privacy; intellectual property; code of ethics and professional practices; freedom of speech and the internet; and ethical hacking. Students who request a credit recommendation for TEEX-0278 cannot receive a credit recommendation for TEEX-0250. Prerequisities:AWR175 Information Security for Everyone.
4fd678b0-adee-496e-bd67-62b03cc17f8e.name: Cyber Ethics (AWR174)(v.1)

issuer.summary: issued by Texas A&M Engineering Extension Service

badge_template_activities.title: The methods of assessment include quizzes and examinations with a minimum passing score of 70 percent.
The methods of instruction include computer-based training.

18efffc1-05bd-4f3c-950b-768bd174aea3.description: The course provides an introduction to computer crime issues from a legal perspective. This course covers intellectual property law (copyright, trade secrets, unfair competition, and unfair business practices), personal jurisdiction, electronic commerce and software contracts, telecommunications, antitrust, privacy, the right to accuracy of information, the right to access to information, and the First Amendment. Students cannot receive a credit recommendation for both TEEX-0277 and TEEX-0250.
18efffc1-05bd-4f3c-950b-768bd174aea3.name: Cyber Law and White-Collar Crime (AWR-168)(v.1)

a9278257-c261-439c-8d45-e80ad99cbd93.description: The course objective is to educate students with some background in IT that lack information security skills. The general course topics include security concepts; TCP/IP networking; network security; operating system security; and encryption. Students cannot receive credit for both TEEX-0251 and TEEX-0282.
a9278257-c261-439c-8d45-e80ad99cbd93.name: Information Security Basics (AWR173)(v.1)

461308e8-da1d-473d-b1d5-0b5572c1ca30.description: The course objective is to provide an introduction to the concepts of digital forensics such as acquisition, extraction, preservation, analysis and deposition of digital evidence from electronic devices. TEEX-0280 and TEEX-0281 must both be completed to earn credit. Students cannot receive credit for both TEEX-0251 and TEEX-0281.
461308e8-da1d-473d-b1d5-0b5572c1ca30.name: Digital Forensics Basics (AWR139)(v.1)

749c5fbd-d1a4-45a7-a6ca-cf2974e23d19.description: The course objective is to educate network administrators, management, or information assurance professionals interested in keeping their systems safe from intrusion, as well as learning how to track incidents when they happen. Students cannot receive credit for both TEEX-0252 and TEEX-0284. Prerequisites: AWR175 Information Security for Everyone.
749c5fbd-d1a4-45a7-a6ca-cf2974e23d19.name: Cyber Incident Analysis and Response (AWR169)(v.1)

a277a96b-37f1-4402-86c9-c186d2d5caa8.description: The course objective is to educate all computer users on internet security. The general course topics include securing new and corrupted computers; protecting computers and their contents; securing computer networks; maintaining privacy; safe internet usage; and protecting and securing mobile and gaming devices. Students who request a credit recommendation for TEEX-0279 cannot receive a credit recommendation for TEEX-0250.
a277a96b-37f1-4402-86c9-c186d2d5caa8.name: Information Security for Everyone (AWR175)

Students cannot receive credit for both TEEX-0251 and TEEX-0283. Prerequisites: AWR173 Information Security Basics; AWR 175 Information Security for Everyone.

Prerequisites: AWR 173 Information Security Basics; AWR 175 Information Security for Everyone.

821933bc-d8d7-4a0a-8bac-d6637a6d252f.description: The course provides an introduction to the fundamentals of risk management in the IT and information management arena. 935efe40-6f90-4676-b350-806fc26553c0.description: The course objective is to provide requisite background theory and recommended best practices needed by business managers to keep their offices running during cyber incidents of different types. Students must complete Cyber Incident Analysis and Response AWR169, Disaster Recovery for Information Systems WR176, Information Risk Management AWR177, Network Security for Homes and Small Businesses AWR396, and Detecting and Responding to a Cyber Attack AWR399 to receive credit.
935efe40-6f90-4676-b350-806fc26553c0.name: Cyber Security for Business Professionals (CYB301)(v.3)

Upon completion of the course, participants will be able to demonstrate how to professionally testify at a trial.

045a3d1f-a281-403d-b6c3-c724e7d70c04.description: The course objective is to educate law enforcement and non-commissioned personnel assigned to crime scene investigation. The general course topics include coroner and medical examiner systems; types of trauma; postmortem factors and processes; body of evidence; investigating specific types of death; death investigation procedures; child death; decedents in a hospital setting; autopsy, lab, and specialist capabilities; and stress.
045a3d1f-a281-403d-b6c3-c724e7d70c04.name: Death Investigation (FSA110)

b70546ec-9660-48c5-8d02-74dd33f0eb25.description: The course objective is to educate law enforcement and non-law enforcement personnel involved in criminal investigations and crime scene analysis, including detectives, investigators, crime scene technicians, forensic technicians, and District Attorneys' investigators. b70546ec-9660-48c5-8d02-74dd33f0eb25.name: Forensic Entomology (FSA102)

The general course topics include macro photography; nighttime photography; reciprocity failure; flash photography; painting with light; shooting reconstruction; bloodstain photography; ultraviolet light photography; infrared light photography; and artistic flair.

3931011d-acf4-420a-b41d-03355b1dd3aa.description: The course objective is to educate individuals who want to become latent print examiners. The general course topics include legal and administrative issues related to friction skin comparison; friction skin development; taking known exemplars; level one detail; classification systems; ACE-V methodology; documentation; comparisons; and court issues. Prerequisites: FSA115 Foundations of Fingerprint Comparison.
3931011d-acf4-420a-b41d-03355b1dd3aa.name: Latent Print Comparison I (FSA120)

4f605c61-d5a1-4e92-bf65-1b82b2033c1a.name: Latent Print Comparison I (FSA120)(v.2)

The general course topics include fingerprint evidence; powder processing; difficult surfaces; chemicals, dyes, and non-powder processes; blood print processing; and DNA and latent prints.
b3dd16a3-beca-4ee9-ab75-fa11256771b4.name: Latent Print Processing (FSA104)

94229cf4-af3b-4d65-8d3b-e7715fbcc9d0.name: Latent Print Processing (FSA104)(v.2)

The general course topics include basics of forensic anthropology; human osteology; biological profile; site identification; recovery of scattered surface and buried remains; decomposition and taphonomy; photography and mapping; and mass disaster.
